channel.title: [PI] How to view someone's Password on Character File?
channel.description:
Hi,
I know there's a way to translate the numbers into words, just not sure how to do it. How can I transfer the numbers of someone's password to letters? Thanks!

item.title: [PI] How to view someone's Password on Character File?
item.dc:creator: @Valance Valance
item.source: [PI] How to view someone's Password on Character File?

item.title: [PI] How to view someone's Password on Character File?
item.dc:creator: @whitefang1 whitefang1
item.description:
@whitefang1 wrote:

[quote=“I Vain I”]It encrypts them with a simple encryption, thus the name is ‘basicEncrypt()’

Here is a key of characters:

A: 65
a: 97
B: 66
b: 98
C: 67
c: 99
D: 68
d: 100
E: 69
e: 101
F: 70
f: 102
G: 71
g: 103
H: 72
h: 104
I: 73
i: 105
J: 74
j: 106
K: 75
k: 107
L: 76
l: 108
M: 77
m: 109
N: 78
n: 110
O: 79
o: 111
P: 80
p: 112
Q: 81
q: 113
R: 82
r: 114
S: 83
s: 115
T: 84
t: 116
U: 85
u: 117
V: 86
v: 118
W: 87
w: 119
X: 88
x: 120
Y: 89
y: 121
Z: 90
z: 122
0: 48
1: 49
2: 50
3: 51
4: 52
5: 53
6: 54
7: 55
8: 56
9: 57

The first character is the character in their real password, the second would be the character is shows in the file.

Such as,

Your password appears as ‘10097110105101108515153’

Lets separate it.

‘100 97 110 105 101 108 51 51 53’

Now, let’s decrypt it.
(Please refer to the key)

100 = d
97 = a
110 = n
105 = i
101 = e
108 = l
51 = 3
51 = 3
53 = 5

So, your password would be ‘daniel335’ in standard format.[/quote]
sweeet, thanks

Read full topic

The first character is the character in their real password, the second would be the character is shows in the file.

Such as,

Your password appears as ‘10097110105101108515153’

Lets separate it.

‘100 97 110 105 101 108 51 51 53’

100 = d
97 = a

105 = i
101 = e
108 = l

51 = 3
53 = 5

So, your password would be ‘daniel335’ in standard format.[/quote]

wow! i never knew that! thats cool.
